In luxury resorts, eco is the flavor du jour.

Just a few years ago, ''eco-resort'' referred mainly to crunchy retreats in places like Costa Rica where even the cat's leftovers were composted. But with ''sustainability'' now a buzzword in nearly every industry, green is becoming the new normal in luxury hotels. According to the International Ecotourism Society, the eco-tourism category grew three times faster than the industry as a whole in 2004. Marketers attribute the growth to a group they call ''metrospirituals'' -- hybrid-driving, yoga-practicing baby- and echo-boomers for whom social responsibility and seeking out new adventures are a way of life.

While progressively more luxurious eco-resorts have been opening in early-adopting regions, the boom is currently spreading to more surprising destinations -- like megapolluting Brazil. ''Anyone with any feeling for the world is going green,'' says the cult interior designer Anouska Hempel, who is at work on Warapuru, a lavish eco-resort set to open next year on Brazil's north coast; made entirely of locally sourced materials, it will have customized spa treatments using native plants (www.warapuru.com).

China -- home to the world's 10 most polluted cities -- gets its first fully sustainable five-star eco-resort next month with Crosswaters Ecolodge (011-86-0752-7693-666; www.crosswaters.com.cn; doubles from $280); guests in this Guangdong retreat will visit a Keija tribal village and sleep in bamboo aeries. In the Western Ghats of India, the New York architect Steven Harris has broken ground on the 3,000-acre Shilim Eco-Resort, where many rooms will have private bathing gardens with infinity pools. And in developing Mozambique, Guludo Beach Lodge recently opened in Quirimbas National Park: nine tented oceanfront suites by the London architects Cullum & Nightingale (www.bespokeexperience.com; doubles from $235).

Closer to home, the Orchard Garden Hotel opens next month in San Francisco (888-717-2881; www.theorchardgardenhotel.com; doubles from $149), the first urban hotel in America to earn the United States Green Building Council's LEED certification. In the Caribbean region, Ritz-Carlton is trailblazing with the Ã¼ber-luxe West Caicos Reserve in the Turks and Caicos, where roads won't have tar, and vegetation won't be disrupted beyond three feet of the buildings.

No doubt surging energy costs and media attention to climate change are powering this Al Gore effect. For developers, the bottom line helps, too. ''Once eco-friendly systems are paid down,'' says Christina Koch, the editor of Eco-structure magazine, ''these buildings are not paying for electricity. It's cost-effective.''

The take-away for travelers: guilt-free luxury. ''If eco-lodges were the vegans of the industry, this new breed is vegetarian,'' says Hitesh Mehta from EDSA, the architects behind Crosswaters. Meat-free, but with a Michelin-star chef.
